text: im going to manually push the v0.2.0 vagrant baseimage, since I have it already built from previous testing
it looks like the docker pipeline did its job though
<@U0UHG4VP1> we should brainstorm on alternative options for vagrant building
i think there are reliability issues with the openstack setup in this regard
few options: we could have a dedicated and/or different build for vagrant
we could get an atlas account
(they do hosted builds, but its no longer free)
who setup the CI for the `fabric-sdk-node` repo?
garisingh: I did
oh, sorry, I didn't
No worries.  I was asking because we need to update the NodeJS version being used
looks like <@U11HH3P7Y> did
Ok.  Thx.  Will check with him
garisingh if it’s straightforward you could check out <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/ci-management> and make the change there
Ah - that is a good idea.  Will go that route.  Thanks
<@U0PB67X4K> what version of nodejs do you need, exactly?
v6.7 or higher
when does this upgrade need to happen? would it be OK if I did it this afternoon? I’ll need to update the image
That's perfect.
I have been manually verifying for now so not a problem

<@U0KM61BCP> <@U0UHG4VP1>: can you please create `<http://hyperledger.github.io|hyperledger.github.io>` github repository in `hyperledger` org. to publish node-sdk html documents. I have created one with <http://hyperledger.github.io|hyperledger.github.io> in my repository but the result page is showing like this.. <https://rameshthoomu.github.io/hyperledger.github.io/>
when I have organization and repository name same, the result page will display as <http://hyperledger.github.io|hyperledger.github.io>
<@U11HH3P7Y>  how do I get started with including fabric-sdk-java in CI builds
nm.. I see your response to my earlier question
<@U0UHG4VP1>: ping
<@U0KPFAZNF>: yes sir?
i see a potential storm on the horizon related to the current disconnect we have between what runs the CI processes and what we use elsewhere such as devenv
and I am wondering if we can address that by unifying them more
heres an example: <@U0XQ35CDD> has been waiting for the golang v1.7 update for a while, presumably so he can use some of the new facilities
<@U0XQ35CDD|kostas> has joined the channel
i am on the verge of having this support available via the baseimage v0.2.0 activity
however, if he were to then code a change in fabric.git, it might not compile in Jenkins without further action on your part
and then there is the issue of, we could simply upgrade jenkins to 1.7, but what implications might that have for older fabric.git
what I am wondering is: is there a way we can structure infra so that there is a tigher relationship with the CI “baseimage” similar to how we have a coupling to the vagrant and docker baseimages
few different thoughts:  we could have a third output of baseimage.git (say, OVS) that is used by jenkins
another idea: we could run the tests inside docker
(since we already have docker baseimage)
third idea: there are integrations to run jenkins jobs inside vagrant, so that could use the existing vagrant baseimage
im open to other ideas as well, of course
those are just to get the conversation started
I'm open to the easiest way forward that doesn't hamstring us later
to me: the docker model seems like the lightest weight path forward on several fronts
Since we have docker base images and can build ... yes
for one, we already publish it
I agree
and second, its the lightest weight option
(in terms of VM overhead)
ok, well lets use that as the operational model for a POC until we find we cant or have a better idea
Agreed
We could probably, if required, set up a second type of builder using a different image (go 1.7)
It might be easier to have specific builds go to specific classes of builders
And avoid new docker builds
Yes, though I am inclined to try to stick it under baseimage since it basically already captures the dependency
OK
We could have the Jenkins job just read .baseimage-release, and then boot stage 2 inside that
ill play around in the sandbox
looking at vagrant in ci-management, we’re currently building `docker pull hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:x86_64-0.0.10`
no reason that couldn’t be re-run as the first line of build
right, and then we just need to adapt what happens next in the context of a docker-run
the bigger challenge will likely be trying to get UTs to run inside a docker container
(or maybe not, who knows
but that is where I expect the most friction
aren’t we sort-of doing that already?
well, we launch docker processes, but we dont do the actual build inside them
at least, not in the same way we do it outside
ah OK.
i think its all doable, it just might require some tweaking
<@U0PB67X4K> Jenkins is now using Node 6.9.1
sorry it took so long
<@U11HH3P7Y> I was finally able to get on to github, I created the new repo <https://hyperledger.github.io/>
<@U11HH3P7Y> maybe the node documentation should be one level down? other projects might want to public documentation here
I would suggest that anything that alters top level namespace should probably flow through TSC approval
